title: How were the attitudes of the 1920s represented by the Flappers? - Quora
tags: History of the United States of America

response.answer_text: The really short answer is that the flappers were decadent and flamboyant, given to excess, averse to the stuffy sobriety and rigid adherence to social convention which had so constrained the Victorians just a decade before.  The twenties indeed roared and the parties, featuring the music du jour, Jazz, went all night, fueled by bootleg gin made more delicious and consumed much more heavily for being illegal. If all good things have a price, then the bill came due for these bon vivants on the terrible October day in 1929 when the color drained from the world for almost everyone.

The flappers represent freedom, liberty, materialism and sex. Some also argue that it heralded a new age of women empowerment. The post war roaring twenties represented exactly that sort of values as morals became increasingly ignored and materialism took root in our culture. So yes, the Flappers are the epitome of the roaring twenties. No doubt
